121
122    @classmethod
123    def _new_from_mapping(cls, dice_counts: Mapping['icepool.Die[T]', int],
124                          outcomes: tuple[T, ...],
125                          keep_tuple: tuple[int, ...]) -> 'Pool[T]':
126        """Creates a new pool.
127
128        Args:
129            dice_counts: A map from dice to rolls.
130            keep_tuple: A tuple with length equal to the number of dice.
131        """
132        dice = tuple(sorted(dice_counts.items(),
133                            key=lambda kv: kv[0].hash_key))
134        return Pool._new_raw(dice, outcomes, keep_tuple)
135
136    def _make_source(self):
137        return PoolSource(self._dice, self._outcomes, self._keep_tuple)
138
139    @cached_property
140    def _raw_size(self) -> int:
141        return sum(count for _, count in self._dice)
142
143    def raw_size(self) -> int:
144        """The number of dice in this pool before the keep_tuple is applied."""
145        return self._raw_size
146
147    @cached_property
148    def _denominator(self) -> int:
149        return math.prod(die.denominator()**count for die, count in self._dice)
150
151    def denominator(self) -> int:
152        return self._denominator
153
154    @cached_property
155    def _dice_tuple(self) -> tuple['icepool.Die[T]', ...]:
156        return sum(((die, ) * count for die, count in self._dice), start=())
157
158    @cached_property
159    def _unique_dice(self) -> Collection['icepool.Die[T]']:
160        return set(die for die, _ in self._dice)
161
162    def unique_dice(self) -> Collection['icepool.Die[T]']:
163        """The collection of unique dice in this pool."""
164        return self._unique_dice
165
166    def outcomes(self) -> Sequence[T]:
167        """The union of possible outcomes among all dice in this pool in ascending order."""
168        return self._outcomes
169
170    def _set_keep_tuple(self, keep_tuple: tuple[int,
171                                                ...]) -> 'KeepGenerator[T]':
172        return Pool._new_raw(self._dice, self._outcomes, keep_tuple)
173
174    def additive_union(
175        *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
176    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
177        args = tuple(
178            icepool.expression.multiset_expression.
179            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
180        if all(isinstance(arg, Pool) for arg in args):
181            pools = cast(tuple[Pool[T], ...], args)
182            keep_tuple: tuple[int, ...] = tuple(
183                reduce(operator.add, (pool.keep_tuple() for pool in pools),
184                       ()))
185            if len(keep_tuple) == 0 or all(x == keep_tuple[0]
186                                           for x in keep_tuple):
187                # All sorted positions count the same, so we can merge the
188                # pools.
189                dice: 'MutableMapping[icepool.Die, int]' = defaultdict(int)
190                for pool in pools:
191                    for die, die_count in pool._dice:
192                        dice[die] += die_count
193                outcomes = icepool.sorted_union(*(pool.outcomes()
194                                                  for pool in pools))
195                return Pool._new_from_mapping(dice, outcomes, keep_tuple)
196        return KeepGenerator.additive_union(*args)
197
198    @property
199    def hash_key(self):
200        return Pool, self._dice, self._keep_tuple
201
202    def __str__(self) -> str:
203        return (
204            f'Pool of {self.raw_size()} dice with keep_tuple={self.keep_tuple()}\n'
205            + ''.join(f'  {repr(die)} : {count},\n'
206                      for die, count in self._dice))

Represents a multiset of outcomes resulting from the roll of several dice.

This should be used in conjunction with MultisetEvaluator to generate a result.

Note that operators are performed on the multiset of rolls, not the multiset of dice. For example, d6.pool(3) - d6.pool(3) is not an empty pool, but an expression meaning "roll two pools of 3d6 and get the rolls from the first pool, with rolls in the second pool cancelling matching rolls in the first pool one-for-one".

@classmethod
def clear_cache(cls): 
117    @classmethod
118    def clear_cache(cls):
119        """Clears the global PoolSource cache."""
120        PoolSource._new_raw.cache_clear()

Clears the global PoolSource cache.

def raw_size(self) -> int: 
143    def raw_size(self) -> int:
144        """The number of dice in this pool before the keep_tuple is applied."""
145        return self._raw_size

The number of dice in this pool before the keep_tuple is applied.

def denominator(self) -> int: 
151    def denominator(self) -> int:
152        return self._denominator
def unique_dice(self) -> Collection[Die[~T]]: 
162    def unique_dice(self) -> Collection['icepool.Die[T]']:
163        """The collection of unique dice in this pool."""
164        return self._unique_dice

The collection of unique dice in this pool.

def outcomes(self) -> Sequence[~T]: 
166    def outcomes(self) -> Sequence[T]:
167        """The union of possible outcomes among all dice in this pool in ascending order."""
168        return self._outcomes

The union of possible outcomes among all dice in this pool in ascending order.

def additive_union( *args: Union[MultisetExpression[~T], Mapping[~T, int], Sequence[~T]]) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
174    def additive_union(
175        *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
176    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
177        args = tuple(
178            icepool.expression.multiset_expression.
179            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
180        if all(isinstance(arg, Pool) for arg in args):
181            pools = cast(tuple[Pool[T], ...], args)
182            keep_tuple: tuple[int, ...] = tuple(
183                reduce(operator.add, (pool.keep_tuple() for pool in pools),
184                       ()))
185            if len(keep_tuple) == 0 or all(x == keep_tuple[0]
186                                           for x in keep_tuple):
187                # All sorted positions count the same, so we can merge the
188                # pools.
189                dice: 'MutableMapping[icepool.Die, int]' = defaultdict(int)
190                for pool in pools:
191                    for die, die_count in pool._dice:
192                        dice[die] += die_count
193                outcomes = icepool.sorted_union(*(pool.outcomes()
194                                                  for pool in pools))
195                return Pool._new_from_mapping(dice, outcomes, keep_tuple)
196        return KeepGenerator.additive_union(*args)

The combined elements from all of the multisets.

Same as a + b + c + ....

Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.

Example:

[1, 2, 2, 3] + [1, 2, 4] -> [1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 4]
hash_key 
198    @property
199    def hash_key(self):
200        return Pool, self._dice, self._keep_tuple

A hash key for this object. This should include a type.

If None, this will not compare equal to any other object.

Inherited Members
icepool.typing.MaybeHashKeyed
equals
def standard_pool( die_sizes: Union[Collection[int], Mapping[int, int]]) -> Pool[int]: 
344def standard_pool(
345        die_sizes: Collection[int] | Mapping[int, int]) -> 'Pool[int]':
346    """A `Pool` of standard dice (e.g. d6, d8...).
347
348    Args:
349        die_sizes: A collection of die sizes, which will put one die of that
350            sizes in the pool for each element.
351            Or, a mapping of die sizes to how many dice of that size to put
352            into the pool.
353            If empty, the pool will be considered to consist of zero zeros.
354    """
355    if not die_sizes:
356        return Pool({icepool.Die([0]): 0})
357    if isinstance(die_sizes, Mapping):
358        die_sizes = list(
359            itertools.chain.from_iterable([k] * v
360                                          for k, v in die_sizes.items()))
361    return Pool(list(icepool.d(x) for x in die_sizes))

A Pool of standard dice (e.g. d6, d8...).

Arguments:
  • die_sizes: A collection of die sizes, which will put one die of that sizes in the pool for each element. Or, a mapping of die sizes to how many dice of that size to put into the pool. If empty, the pool will be considered to consist of zero zeros.
class MultisetGenerator(icepool.MultisetExpression[~T]): 
17class MultisetGenerator(MultisetExpression[T]):
18    """Abstract base class for generating multisets.
19
20    These include dice pools (`Pool`) and card deals (`Deal`). Most likely you
21    will be using one of these two rather than writing your own subclass of
22    `MultisetGenerator`.
23
24    The multisets are incrementally generated one outcome at a time.
25    For each outcome, a `count` and `weight` are generated, along with a
26    smaller generator to produce the rest of the multiset.
27
28    You can perform simple evaluations using built-in operators and methods in
29    this class.
30    For more complex evaluations and better performance, particularly when
31    multiple generators are involved, you will want to write your own subclass
32    of `MultisetEvaluator`.
33    """
34
35    _children = ()
36
37    @abstractmethod
38    def _make_source(self) -> 'MultisetSource':
39        """Create a source from this generator."""
40
41    @property
42    def _has_param(self) -> bool:
43        return False
44
45    def _prepare(
46        self
47    ) -> Iterator[tuple['tuple[Dungeonlet[T, Any], ...]',
48                        'tuple[Questlet[T, Any], ...]',
49                        'tuple[MultisetSourceBase[T, Any], ...]', int]]:
50        dungeonlets = (MultisetFreeVariable[T, int](), )
51        questlets = (MultisetGeneratorQuestlet[T](), )
52        sources = (self._make_source(), )
53        weight = 1
54        yield dungeonlets, questlets, sources, weight

Abstract base class for generating multisets.

These include dice pools (Pool) and card deals (Deal). Most likely you will be using one of these two rather than writing your own subclass of MultisetGenerator.

The multisets are incrementally generated one outcome at a time. For each outcome, a count and weight are generated, along with a smaller generator to produce the rest of the multiset.

You can perform simple evaluations using built-in operators and methods in this class. For more complex evaluations and better performance, particularly when multiple generators are involved, you will want to write your own subclass of MultisetEvaluator.

Inherited Members
icepool.typing.MaybeHashKeyed
hash_key
equals
class MultisetExpression(icepool.expression.multiset_expression_base.MultisetExpressionBase[~T, int], icepool.expand.Expandable[tuple[~T, ...]]): 
  65class MultisetExpression(MultisetExpressionBase[T, int],
  66                         Expandable[tuple[T, ...]]):
  67    """Abstract base class representing an expression that operates on single multisets.
  68
  69    There are three types of multiset expressions:
  70
  71    * `MultisetGenerator`, which produce raw outcomes and counts.
  72    * `MultisetOperator`, which takes outcomes with one or more counts and
  73        produces a count.
  74    * `MultisetVariable`, which is a temporary placeholder for some other 
  75        expression.
  76
  77    Expression methods can be applied to `MultisetGenerator`s to do simple
  78    evaluations. For joint evaluations, try `multiset_function`.
  79
  80    Use the provided operations to build up more complicated
  81    expressions, or to attach a final evaluator.
  82
  83    Operations include:
  84
  85    | Operation                   | Count / notes                               |
  86    |:----------------------------|:--------------------------------------------|
  87    | `additive_union`, `+`       | `l + r`                                     |
  88    | `difference`, `-`           | `l - r`                                     |
  89    | `intersection`, `&`         | `min(l, r)`                                 |
  90    | `union`, `\\|`               | `max(l, r)`                                 |
  91    | `symmetric_difference`, `^` | `abs(l - r)`                                |
  92    | `multiply_counts`, `*`      | `count * n`                                 |
  93    | `divide_counts`, `//`       | `count // n`                                |
  94    | `modulo_counts`, `%`        | `count % n`                                 |
  95    | `keep_counts`               | `count if count >= n else 0` etc.           |
  96    | unary `+`                   | same as `keep_counts_ge(0)`                 |
  97    | unary `-`                   | reverses the sign of all counts             |
  98    | `unique`                    | `min(count, n)`                             |
  99    | `keep_outcomes`             | `count if outcome in t else 0`              |
 100    | `drop_outcomes`             | `count if outcome not in t else 0`          |
 101    | `map_counts`                | `f(outcome, *counts)`                       |
 102    | `keep`, `[]`                | less capable than `KeepGenerator` version   |
 103    | `highest`                   | less capable than `KeepGenerator` version   |
 104    | `lowest`                    | less capable than `KeepGenerator` version   |
 105
 106    | Evaluator                      | Summary                                                                    |
 107    |:-------------------------------|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------|
 108    | `issubset`, `<=`               | Whether the left side's counts are all <= their counterparts on the right  |
 109    | `issuperset`, `>=`             | Whether the left side's counts are all >= their counterparts on the right  |
 110    | `isdisjoint`                   | Whether the left side has no positive counts in common with the right side |
 111    | `<`                            | As `<=`, but `False` if the two multisets are equal                        |
 112    | `>`                            | As `>=`, but `False` if the two multisets are equal                        |
 113    | `==`                           | Whether the left side has all the same counts as the right side            |
 114    | `!=`                           | Whether the left side has any different counts to the right side           |
 115    | `expand`                       | All elements in ascending order                                            |
 116    | `sum`                          | Sum of all elements                                                        |
 117    | `count`                        | The number of elements                                                     |
 118    | `any`                          | Whether there is at least 1 element                                        |
 119    | `highest_outcome_and_count`    | The highest outcome and how many of that outcome                           |
 120    | `all_counts`                   | All counts in descending order                                             |
 121    | `largest_count`                | The single largest count, aka x-of-a-kind                                  |
 122    | `largest_count_and_outcome`    | Same but also with the corresponding outcome                               |
 123    | `count_subset`, `//`           | The number of times the right side is contained in the left side           |
 124    | `largest_straight`             | Length of longest consecutive sequence                                     |
 125    | `largest_straight_and_outcome` | Same but also with the corresponding outcome                               |
 126    | `all_straights`                | Lengths of all consecutive sequences in descending order                   |
 127    """
 128
 129    def _make_param(self, index: int, name: str) -> 'MultisetParameter[T]':
 130        return icepool.MultisetParameter(index, name)
 131
 132    @property
 133    def _items_for_cartesian_product(
 134            self) -> Sequence[tuple[tuple[T, ...], int]]:
 135        expansion = cast('icepool.Die[tuple[T, ...]]', self.expand())
 136        return expansion.items()
 137
 138    # We need to reiterate this since we override __eq__.
 139    __hash__ = MaybeHashKeyed.__hash__  # type: ignore
 140
 141    # Binary operators.
 142
 143    def __add__(self,
 144                other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 145                /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 146        try:
 147            return MultisetExpression.additive_union(self, other)
 148        except ImplicitConversionError:
 149            return NotImplemented
 150
 151    def __radd__(
 152            self,
 153            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 154            /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 155        try:
 156            return MultisetExpression.additive_union(other, self)
 157        except ImplicitConversionError:
 158            return NotImplemented
 159
 160    def additive_union(
 161        *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
 162    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 163        """The combined elements from all of the multisets.
 164
 165        Same as `a + b + c + ...`.
 166
 167        Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.
 168
 169        Example:
 170        ```python
 171        [1, 2, 2, 3] + [1, 2, 4] -> [1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 4]
 172        ```
 173        """
 174        expressions = tuple(
 175            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
 176        return icepool.operator.MultisetAdditiveUnion(*expressions)
 177
 178    def __sub__(self,
 179                other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 180                /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 181        try:
 182            return MultisetExpression.difference(self, other)
 183        except ImplicitConversionError:
 184            return NotImplemented
 185
 186    def __rsub__(
 187            self,
 188            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 189            /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 190        try:
 191            return MultisetExpression.difference(other, self)
 192        except ImplicitConversionError:
 193            return NotImplemented
 194
 195    def difference(
 196        *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
 197    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 198        """The elements from the left multiset that are not in any of the others.
 199
 200        Same as `a - b - c - ...`.
 201
 202        Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.
 203
 204        Example:
 205        ```python
 206        [1, 2, 2, 3] - [1, 2, 4] -> [2, 3]
 207        ```
 208
 209        If no arguments are given, the result will be an empty multiset, i.e.
 210        all zero counts.
 211
 212        Note that, as a multiset operation, this will only cancel elements 1:1.
 213        If you want to drop all elements in a set of outcomes regardless of
 214        count, either use `drop_outcomes()` instead, or use a large number of
 215        counts on the right side.
 216        """
 217        expressions = tuple(
 218            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
 219        return icepool.operator.MultisetDifference(*expressions)
 220
 221    def __and__(self,
 222                other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 223                /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 224        try:
 225            return MultisetExpression.intersection(self, other)
 226        except ImplicitConversionError:
 227            return NotImplemented
 228
 229    def __rand__(
 230            self,
 231            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 232            /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 233        try:
 234            return MultisetExpression.intersection(other, self)
 235        except ImplicitConversionError:
 236            return NotImplemented
 237
 238    def intersection(
 239        *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
 240    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 241        """The elements that all the multisets have in common.
 242
 243        Same as `a & b & c & ...`.
 244
 245        Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.
 246
 247        Example:
 248        ```python
 249        [1, 2, 2, 3] & [1, 2, 4] -> [1, 2]
 250        ```
 251
 252        Note that, as a multiset operation, this will only intersect elements
 253        1:1.
 254        If you want to keep all elements in a set of outcomes regardless of
 255        count, either use `keep_outcomes()` instead, or use a large number of
 256        counts on the right side.
 257        """
 258        expressions = tuple(
 259            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
 260        return icepool.operator.MultisetIntersection(*expressions)
 261
 262    def __or__(self,
 263               other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 264               /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 265        try:
 266            return MultisetExpression.union(self, other)
 267        except ImplicitConversionError:
 268            return NotImplemented
 269
 270    def __ror__(self,
 271                other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 272                /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 273        try:
 274            return MultisetExpression.union(other, self)
 275        except ImplicitConversionError:
 276            return NotImplemented
 277
 278    def union(
 279        *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
 280    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 281        """The most of each outcome that appear in any of the multisets.
 282
 283        Same as `a | b | c | ...`.
 284
 285        Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.
 286
 287        Example:
 288        ```python
 289        [1, 2, 2, 3] | [1, 2, 4] -> [1, 2, 2, 3, 4]
 290        ```
 291        """
 292        expressions = tuple(
 293            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
 294        return icepool.operator.MultisetUnion(*expressions)
 295
 296    def __xor__(self,
 297                other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 298                /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 299        try:
 300            return MultisetExpression.symmetric_difference(self, other)
 301        except ImplicitConversionError:
 302            return NotImplemented
 303
 304    def __rxor__(
 305            self,
 306            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 307            /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 308        try:
 309            # Symmetric.
 310            return MultisetExpression.symmetric_difference(self, other)
 311        except ImplicitConversionError:
 312            return NotImplemented
 313
 314    def symmetric_difference(
 315            self,
 316            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 317            /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 318        """The elements that appear in the left or right multiset but not both.
 319
 320        Same as `a ^ b`.
 321
 322        Specifically, this produces the absolute difference between counts.
 323        If you don't want negative counts to be used from the inputs, you can
 324        do `+left ^ +right`.
 325
 326        Example:
 327        ```python
 328        [1, 2, 2, 3] ^ [1, 2, 4] -> [2, 3, 4]
 329        ```
 330        """
 331        return icepool.operator.MultisetSymmetricDifference(
 332            self, implicit_convert_to_expression(other))
 333
 334    def keep_outcomes(
 335            self, target:
 336        'Callable[[T], bool] | Collection[T] | MultisetExpression[T]',
 337            /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 338        """Keeps the elements in the target set of outcomes, and drops the rest by setting their counts to zero.
 339
 340        This is similar to `intersection()`, except the right side is considered
 341        to have unlimited multiplicity.
 342
 343        Args:
 344            target: A callable returning `True` iff the outcome should be kept,
 345                or an expression or collection of outcomes to keep.
 346        """
 347        if isinstance(target, MultisetExpression):
 348            return icepool.operator.MultisetFilterOutcomesBinary(self, target)
 349        else:
 350            return icepool.operator.MultisetFilterOutcomes(self, target=target)
 351
 352    def drop_outcomes(
 353            self, target:
 354        'Callable[[T], bool] | Collection[T] | MultisetExpression[T]',
 355            /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 356        """Drops the elements in the target set of outcomes by setting their counts to zero, and keeps the rest.
 357
 358        This is similar to `difference()`, except the right side is considered
 359        to have unlimited multiplicity.
 360
 361        Args:
 362            target: A callable returning `True` iff the outcome should be
 363                dropped, or an expression or collection of outcomes to drop.
 364        """
 365        if isinstance(target, MultisetExpression):
 366            return icepool.operator.MultisetFilterOutcomesBinary(self,
 367                                                                 target,
 368                                                                 invert=True)
 369        else:
 370            return icepool.operator.MultisetFilterOutcomes(self,
 371                                                           target=target,
 372                                                           invert=True)
 373
 374    # Adjust counts.
 375
 376    def map_counts(*args:
 377                   'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 378                   function: Callable[..., int]) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 379        """Maps the counts to new counts.
 380
 381        Args:
 382            function: A function that takes `outcome, *counts` and produces a
 383                combined count.
 384        """
 385        expressions = tuple(
 386            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
 387        return icepool.operator.MultisetMapCounts(*expressions,
 388                                                  function=function)
 389
 390    def __mul__(self, n: int) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 391        if not isinstance(n, int):
 392            return NotImplemented
 393        return self.multiply_counts(n)
 394
 395    # Commutable in this case.
 396    def __rmul__(self, n: int) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 397        if not isinstance(n, int):
 398            return NotImplemented
 399        return self.multiply_counts(n)
 400
 401    def multiply_counts(self, n: int, /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 402        """Multiplies all counts by n.
 403
 404        Same as `self * n`.
 405
 406        Example:
 407        ```python
 408        Pool([1, 2, 2, 3]) * 2 -> [1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 2, 3, 3]
 409        ```
 410        """
 411        return icepool.operator.MultisetMultiplyCounts(self, constant=n)
 412
 413    @overload
 414    def __floordiv__(self, other: int) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 415        ...
 416
 417    @overload
 418    def __floordiv__(
 419        self, other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
 420    ) -> 'icepool.Die[int] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, int]':
 421        """Same as divide_counts()."""
 422
 423    @overload
 424    def __floordiv__(
 425        self,
 426        other: 'int | MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
 427    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T] | icepool.Die[int] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, int]':
 428        """Same as count_subset()."""
 429
 430    def __floordiv__(
 431        self,
 432        other: 'int | MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
 433    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T] | icepool.Die[int] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, int]':
 434        if isinstance(other, int):
 435            return self.divide_counts(other)
 436        else:
 437            return self.count_subset(other)
 438
 439    def divide_counts(self, n: int, /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 440        """Divides all counts by n (rounding down).
 441
 442        Same as `self // n`.
 443
 444        Example:
 445        ```python
 446        Pool([1, 2, 2, 3]) // 2 -> [2]
 447        ```
 448        """
 449        return icepool.operator.MultisetFloordivCounts(self, constant=n)
 450
 451    def __mod__(self, n: int, /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 452        if not isinstance(n, int):
 453            return NotImplemented
 454        return icepool.operator.MultisetModuloCounts(self, constant=n)
 455
 456    def modulo_counts(self, n: int, /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 457        """Moduos all counts by n.
 458
 459        Same as `self % n`.
 460
 461        Example:
 462        ```python
 463        Pool([1, 2, 2, 3]) % 2 -> [1, 3]
 464        ```
 465        """
 466        return self % n
 467
 468    def __pos__(self) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 469        """Sets all negative counts to zero."""
 470        return icepool.operator.MultisetKeepCounts(self,
 471                                                   comparison='>=',
 472                                                   constant=0)
 473
 474    def __neg__(self) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 475        """As -1 * self."""
 476        return -1 * self
 477
 478    def keep_counts(self, comparison: Literal['==', '!=', '<=', '<', '>=',
 479                                              '>'], n: int,
 480                    /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 481        """Keeps counts fitting the comparison, treating the rest as zero.
 482
 483        For example, `expression.keep_counts('>=', 2)` would keep pairs,
 484        triplets, etc. and drop singles.
 485
 486        ```python
 487        Pool([1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3]).keep_counts('>=', 2) -> [2, 2, 3, 3, 3]
 488        ```
 489        
 490        Args:
 491            comparison: The comparison to use.
 492            n: The number to compare counts against.
 493        """
 494        return icepool.operator.MultisetKeepCounts(self,
 495                                                   comparison=comparison,
 496                                                   constant=n)
 497
 498    def unique(self, n: int = 1, /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 499        """Counts each outcome at most `n` times.
 500
 501        For example, `generator.unique(2)` would count each outcome at most
 502        twice.
 503
 504        Example:
 505        ```python
 506        Pool([1, 2, 2, 3]).unique() -> [1, 2, 3]
 507        ```
 508        """
 509        return icepool.operator.MultisetUnique(self, constant=n)
 510
 511    # Keep highest / lowest.
 512
 513    @overload
 514    def keep(
 515        self, index: slice | Sequence[int | EllipsisType]
 516    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 517        ...
 518
 519    @overload
 520    def keep(self,
 521             index: int) -> 'icepool.Die[T] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, T]':
 522        ...
 523
 524    def keep(
 525        self, index: slice | Sequence[int | EllipsisType] | int
 526    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T] | icepool.Die[T] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, T]':
 527        """Selects elements after drawing and sorting.
 528
 529        This is less capable than the `KeepGenerator` version.
 530        In particular, it does not know how many elements it is selecting from,
 531        so it must be anchored at the starting end. The advantage is that it
 532        can be applied to any expression.
 533
 534        The valid types of argument are:
 535
 536        * A `slice`. If both start and stop are provided, they must both be
 537            non-negative or both be negative. step is not supported.
 538        * A sequence of `int` with `...` (`Ellipsis`) at exactly one end.
 539            Each sorted element will be counted that many times, with the
 540            `Ellipsis` treated as enough zeros (possibly "negative") to
 541            fill the rest of the elements.
 542        * An `int`, which evaluates by taking the element at the specified
 543            index. In this case the result is a `Die`.
 544
 545        Negative incoming counts are treated as zero counts.
 546
 547        Use the `[]` operator for the same effect as this method.
 548        """
 549        if isinstance(index, int):
 550            return icepool.evaluator.keep_evaluator.evaluate(self, index=index)
 551        else:
 552            return icepool.operator.MultisetKeep(self, index=index)
 553
 554    @overload
 555    def __getitem__(
 556        self, index: slice | Sequence[int | EllipsisType]
 557    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 558        ...
 559
 560    @overload
 561    def __getitem__(
 562            self,
 563            index: int) -> 'icepool.Die[T] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, T]':
 564        ...
 565
 566    def __getitem__(
 567        self, index: slice | Sequence[int | EllipsisType] | int
 568    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T] | icepool.Die[T] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, T]':
 569        return self.keep(index)
 570
 571    def lowest(self,
 572               keep: int | None = None,
 573               drop: int | None = None) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 574        """Keep some of the lowest elements from this multiset and drop the rest.
 575
 576        In contrast to the die and free function versions, this does not
 577        automatically sum the dice. Use `.sum()` afterwards if you want to sum.
 578        Alternatively, you can perform some other evaluation.
 579
 580        This requires the outcomes to be evaluated in ascending order.
 581
 582        Args:
 583            keep, drop: These arguments work together:
 584                * If neither are provided, the single lowest element
 585                    will be kept.
 586                * If only `keep` is provided, the `keep` lowest elements
 587                    will be kept.
 588                * If only `drop` is provided, the `drop` lowest elements
 589                    will be dropped and the rest will be kept.
 590                * If both are provided, `drop` lowest elements will be dropped,
 591                    then the next `keep` lowest elements will be kept.
 592        """
 593        index = lowest_slice(keep, drop)
 594        return self.keep(index)
 595
 596    def highest(self,
 597                keep: int | None = None,
 598                drop: int | None = None) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 599        """Keep some of the highest elements from this multiset and drop the rest.
 600
 601        In contrast to the die and free function versions, this does not
 602        automatically sum the dice. Use `.sum()` afterwards if you want to sum.
 603        Alternatively, you can perform some other evaluation.
 604
 605        This requires the outcomes to be evaluated in descending order.
 606
 607        Args:
 608            keep, drop: These arguments work together:
 609                * If neither are provided, the single highest element
 610                    will be kept.
 611                * If only `keep` is provided, the `keep` highest elements
 612                    will be kept.
 613                * If only `drop` is provided, the `drop` highest elements
 614                    will be dropped and the rest will be kept.
 615                * If both are provided, `drop` highest elements will be dropped, 
 616                    then the next `keep` highest elements will be kept.
 617        """
 618        index = highest_slice(keep, drop)
 619        return self.keep(index)
 620
 621    # Matching.
 622
 623    def sort_match(self,
 624                   comparison: Literal['==', '!=', '<=', '<', '>=', '>'],
 625                   other: 'MultisetExpression[T]',
 626                   /,
 627                   order: Order = Order.Descending) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 628        """EXPERIMENTAL: Matches elements of `self` with elements of `other` in sorted order, then keeps elements from `self` that fit `comparison` with their partner.
 629
 630        Extra elements: If `self` has more elements than `other`, whether the
 631        extra elements are kept depends on the `order` and `comparison`:
 632        * Descending: kept for `'>='`, `'>'`
 633        * Ascending: kept for `'<='`, `'<'`
 634
 635        Example: An attacker rolls 3d6 versus a defender's 2d6 in the game of
 636        *RISK*. Which pairs did the attacker win?
 637        ```python
 638        d6.pool(3).highest(2).sort_match('>', d6.pool(2))
 639        ```
 640        
 641        Suppose the attacker rolled 6, 4, 3 and the defender 5, 5.
 642        In this case the 4 would be blocked since the attacker lost that pair,
 643        leaving the attacker's 6 and 3. If you don't want to keep the extra
 644        element, you can use `highest`.
 645        ```python
 646        Pool([6, 4, 3]).sort_match('>', [5, 5]) -> [6, 3]
 647        Pool([6, 4, 3]).highest(2).sort_match('>', [5, 5]) -> [6]
 648        ```
 649
 650        Contrast `maximum_match()`, which first creates the maximum number of
 651        pairs that fit the comparison, not necessarily in sorted order.
 652        In the above example, `maximum_match()` would allow the defender to
 653        assign their 5s to block both the 4 and the 3.
 654
 655        Negative incoming counts are treated as zero counts.
 656        
 657        Args:
 658            comparison: The comparison to filter by. If you want to drop rather
 659                than keep, use the complementary comparison:
 660                * `'=='` vs. `'!='`
 661                * `'<='` vs. `'>'`
 662                * `'>='` vs. `'<'`
 663            other: The other multiset to match elements with.
 664            order: The order in which to sort before forming matches.
 665                Default is descending.
 666        """
 667        other = implicit_convert_to_expression(other)
 668
 669        match comparison:
 670            case '==':
 671                lesser, tie, greater = 0, 1, 0
 672            case '!=':
 673                lesser, tie, greater = 1, 0, 1
 674            case '<=':
 675                lesser, tie, greater = 1, 1, 0
 676            case '<':
 677                lesser, tie, greater = 1, 0, 0
 678            case '>=':
 679                lesser, tie, greater = 0, 1, 1
 680            case '>':
 681                lesser, tie, greater = 0, 0, 1
 682            case _:
 683                raise ValueError(f'Invalid comparison {comparison}')
 684
 685        if order > 0:
 686            left_first = lesser
 687            right_first = greater
 688        else:
 689            left_first = greater
 690            right_first = lesser
 691
 692        return icepool.operator.MultisetSortMatch(self,
 693                                                  other,
 694                                                  order=order,
 695                                                  tie=tie,
 696                                                  left_first=left_first,
 697                                                  right_first=right_first)
 698
 699    def maximum_match_highest(
 700            self, comparison: Literal['<=',
 701                                      '<'], other: 'MultisetExpression[T]', /,
 702            *, keep: Literal['matched',
 703                             'unmatched']) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 704        """EXPERIMENTAL: Match the highest elements from `self` with even higher (or equal) elements from `other`.
 705
 706        This matches elements of `self` with elements of `other`, such that in
 707        each pair the element from `self` fits the `comparision` with the
 708        element from `other`. As many such pairs of elements will be matched as 
 709        possible, preferring the highest matchable elements of `self`.
 710        Finally, either the matched or unmatched elements from `self` are kept.
 711
 712        This requires that outcomes be evaluated in descending order.
 713
 714        Example: An attacker rolls a pool of 4d6 and a defender rolls a pool of 
 715        3d6. Defender dice can be used to block attacker dice of equal or lesser
 716        value, and the defender prefers to block the highest attacker dice
 717        possible. Which attacker dice were not blocked?
 718        ```python
 719        d6.pool(4).maximum_match('<=', d6.pool(3), keep='unmatched').sum()
 720        ```
 721
 722        Suppose the attacker rolls 6, 4, 3, 1 and the defender rolls 5, 5.
 723        Then the result would be [6, 1].
 724        ```python
 725        d6.pool([6, 4, 3, 1]).maximum_match('<=', [5, 5], keep='unmatched')
 726        -> [6, 1]
 727        ```
 728
 729        Contrast `sort_match()`, which first creates pairs in
 730        sorted order and then filters them by `comparison`.
 731        In the above example, `sort_matched` would force the defender to match
 732        against the 5 and the 4, which would only allow them to block the 4.
 733
 734        Negative incoming counts are treated as zero counts.
 735
 736        Args:
 737            comparison: Either `'<='` or `'<'`.
 738            other: The other multiset to match elements with.
 739            keep: Whether 'matched' or 'unmatched' elements are to be kept.
 740        """
 741        if keep == 'matched':
 742            keep_boolean = True
 743        elif keep == 'unmatched':
 744            keep_boolean = False
 745        else:
 746            raise ValueError(f"keep must be either 'matched' or 'unmatched'")
 747
 748        other = implicit_convert_to_expression(other)
 749        match comparison:
 750            case '<=':
 751                match_equal = True
 752            case '<':
 753                match_equal = False
 754            case _:
 755                raise ValueError(f'Invalid comparison {comparison}')
 756        return icepool.operator.MultisetMaximumMatch(self,
 757                                                     other,
 758                                                     order=Order.Descending,
 759                                                     match_equal=match_equal,
 760                                                     keep=keep_boolean)
 761
 762    def maximum_match_lowest(
 763            self, comparison: Literal['>=',
 764                                      '>'], other: 'MultisetExpression[T]', /,
 765            *, keep: Literal['matched',
 766                             'unmatched']) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
 767        """EXPERIMENTAL: Match the lowest elements from `self` with even lower (or equal) elements from `other`.
 768
 769        This matches elements of `self` with elements of `other`, such that in
 770        each pair the element from `self` fits the `comparision` with the
 771        element from `other`. As many such pairs of elements will be matched as 
 772        possible, preferring the lowest matchable elements of `self`.
 773        Finally, either the matched or unmatched elements from `self` are kept.
 774
 775        This requires that outcomes be evaluated in ascending order.
 776
 777        Contrast `sort_match()`, which first creates pairs in
 778        sorted order and then filters them by `comparison`.
 779
 780        Args:
 781            comparison: Either `'>='` or `'>'`.
 782            other: The other multiset to match elements with.
 783            keep: Whether 'matched' or 'unmatched' elements are to be kept.
 784        """
 785        if keep == 'matched':
 786            keep_boolean = True
 787        elif keep == 'unmatched':
 788            keep_boolean = False
 789        else:
 790            raise ValueError(f"keep must be either 'matched' or 'unmatched'")
 791
 792        other = implicit_convert_to_expression(other)
 793        match comparison:
 794            case '>=':
 795                match_equal = True
 796            case '>':
 797                match_equal = False
 798            case _:
 799                raise ValueError(f'Invalid comparison {comparison}')
 800        return icepool.operator.MultisetMaximumMatch(self,
 801                                                     other,
 802                                                     order=Order.Ascending,
 803                                                     match_equal=match_equal,
 804                                                     keep=keep_boolean)
 805
 806    # Evaluations.
 807
 808    def expand(
 809        self,
 810        order: Order = Order.Ascending
 811    ) -> 'icepool.Die[tuple[T, ...]] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, tuple[T, ...]]':
 812        """Evaluation: All elements of the multiset in ascending order.
 813
 814        This is expensive and not recommended unless there are few possibilities.
 815
 816        Args:
 817            order: Whether the elements are in ascending (default) or descending
 818                order.
 819        """
 820        return icepool.evaluator.ExpandEvaluator().evaluate(self, order=order)
 821
 822    def sum(
 823        self,
 824        map: Callable[[T], U] | Mapping[T, U] | None = None
 825    ) -> 'icepool.Die[U] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, U]':
 826        """Evaluation: The sum of all elements."""
 827        if map is None:
 828            return icepool.evaluator.sum_evaluator.evaluate(self)
 829        else:
 830            return icepool.evaluator.SumEvaluator(map).evaluate(self)
 831
 832    def size(self) -> 'icepool.Die[int] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, int]':
 833        """Evaluation: The total number of elements in the multiset.
 834
 835        This is usually not very interesting unless some other operation is
 836        performed first. Examples:
 837
 838        `generator.unique().size()` will count the number of unique outcomes.
 839
 840        `(generator & [4, 5, 6]).size()` will count up to one each of
 841        4, 5, and 6.
 842        """
 843        return icepool.evaluator.size_evaluator.evaluate(self)
 844
 845    def any(self) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
 846        """Evaluation: Whether the multiset has at least one positive count. """
 847        return icepool.evaluator.any_evaluator.evaluate(self)
 848
 849    def highest_outcome_and_count(
 850        self
 851    ) -> 'icepool.Die[tuple[T, int]] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, tuple[T, int]]':
 852        """Evaluation: The highest outcome with positive count, along with that count.
 853
 854        If no outcomes have positive count, the min outcome will be returned with 0 count.
 855        """
 856        return icepool.evaluator.highest_outcome_and_count_evaluator.evaluate(
 857            self)
 858
 859    def all_counts(
 860        self,
 861        filter: int | Literal['all'] = 1
 862    ) -> 'icepool.Die[tuple[int, ...]] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, tuple[int, ...]]':
 863        """Evaluation: Sorted tuple of all counts, i.e. the sizes of all matching sets.
 864
 865        The sizes are in **descending** order.
 866
 867        Args:
 868            filter: Any counts below this value will not be in the output.
 869                For example, `filter=2` will only produce pairs and better.
 870                If `None`, no filtering will be done.
 871
 872                Why not just place `keep_counts_ge()` before this?
 873                `keep_counts_ge()` operates by setting counts to zero, so you
 874                would still need an argument to specify whether you want to
 875                output zero counts. So we might as well use the argument to do
 876                both.
 877        """
 878        return icepool.evaluator.AllCountsEvaluator(
 879            filter=filter).evaluate(self)
 880
 881    def largest_count(
 882            self) -> 'icepool.Die[int] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, int]':
 883        """Evaluation: The size of the largest matching set among the elements."""
 884        return icepool.evaluator.largest_count_evaluator.evaluate(self)
 885
 886    def largest_count_and_outcome(
 887        self
 888    ) -> 'icepool.Die[tuple[int, T]] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, tuple[int, T]]':
 889        """Evaluation: The largest matching set among the elements and the corresponding outcome."""
 890        return icepool.evaluator.largest_count_and_outcome_evaluator.evaluate(
 891            self)
 892
 893    def __rfloordiv__(
 894        self, other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
 895    ) -> 'icepool.Die[int] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, int]':
 896        return implicit_convert_to_expression(other).count_subset(self)
 897
 898    def count_subset(
 899        self,
 900        divisor: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 901        /,
 902        *,
 903        empty_divisor: int | None = None
 904    ) -> 'icepool.Die[int] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, int]':
 905        """Evaluation: The number of times the divisor is contained in this multiset.
 906        
 907        Args:
 908            divisor: The multiset to divide by.
 909            empty_divisor: If the divisor is empty, the outcome will be this.
 910                If not set, `ZeroDivisionError` will be raised for an empty
 911                right side.
 912
 913        Raises:
 914            ZeroDivisionError: If the divisor may be empty and 
 915                empty_divisor_outcome is not set.
 916        """
 917        divisor = implicit_convert_to_expression(divisor)
 918        return icepool.evaluator.CountSubsetEvaluator(
 919            empty_divisor=empty_divisor).evaluate(self, divisor)
 920
 921    def largest_straight(
 922        self: 'MultisetExpression[int]'
 923    ) -> 'icepool.Die[int] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[int, int]':
 924        """Evaluation: The size of the largest straight among the elements.
 925
 926        Outcomes must be `int`s.
 927        """
 928        return icepool.evaluator.largest_straight_evaluator.evaluate(self)
 929
 930    def largest_straight_and_outcome(
 931        self: 'MultisetExpression[int]',
 932        priority: Literal['low', 'high'] = 'high',
 933        /
 934    ) -> 'icepool.Die[tuple[int, int]] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[int, tuple[int, int]]':
 935        """Evaluation: The size of the largest straight among the elements and the highest (optionally, lowest) outcome in that straight.
 936
 937        Straight size is prioritized first, then the outcome.
 938
 939        Outcomes must be `int`s.
 940
 941        Args:
 942            priority: Controls which outcome within the straight is returned,
 943                and which straight is picked if there is a tie for largest
 944                straight.
 945        """
 946        if priority == 'high':
 947            return icepool.evaluator.largest_straight_and_outcome_evaluator_high.evaluate(
 948                self)
 949        elif priority == 'low':
 950            return icepool.evaluator.largest_straight_and_outcome_evaluator_low.evaluate(
 951                self)
 952        else:
 953            raise ValueError("priority must be 'low' or 'high'.")
 954
 955    def all_straights(
 956        self: 'MultisetExpression[int]'
 957    ) -> 'icepool.Die[tuple[int, ...]] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[int, tuple[int, ...]]':
 958        """Evaluation: The sizes of all straights.
 959
 960        The sizes are in **descending** order.
 961
 962        Each element can only contribute to one straight, though duplicate
 963        elements can produces straights that overlap in outcomes. In this case,
 964        elements are preferentially assigned to the longer straight.
 965        """
 966        return icepool.evaluator.all_straights_evaluator.evaluate(self)
 967
 968    def all_straights_reduce_counts(
 969        self: 'MultisetExpression[int]',
 970        reducer: Callable[[int, int], int] = operator.mul
 971    ) -> 'icepool.Die[tuple[tuple[int, int], ...]] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[int, tuple[tuple[int, int], ...]]':
 972        """Experimental: All straights with a reduce operation on the counts.
 973
 974        This can be used to evaluate e.g. cribbage-style straight counting.
 975
 976        The result is a tuple of `(run_length, run_score)`s.
 977        """
 978        return icepool.evaluator.AllStraightsReduceCountsEvaluator(
 979            reducer=reducer).evaluate(self)
 980
 981    def argsort(self: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 982                *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
 983                order: Order = Order.Descending,
 984                limit: int | None = None):
 985        """Experimental: Returns the indexes of the originating multisets for each rank in their additive union.
 986
 987        Example:
 988        ```python
 989        MultisetExpression.argsort([10, 9, 5], [9, 9])
 990        ```
 991        produces
 992        ```python
 993        ((0,), (0, 1, 1), (0,))
 994        ```
 995        
 996        Args:
 997            self, *args: The multiset expressions to be evaluated.
 998            order: Which order the ranks are to be emitted. Default is descending.
 999            limit: How many ranks to emit. Default will emit all ranks, which
1000                makes the length of each outcome equal to
1001                `additive_union(+self, +arg1, +arg2, ...).unique().size()`
1002        """
1003        self = implicit_convert_to_expression(self)
1004        converted_args = [implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args]
1005        return icepool.evaluator.ArgsortEvaluator(order=order,
1006                                                  limit=limit).evaluate(
1007                                                      self, *converted_args)
1008
1009    # Comparators.
1010
1011    def _compare(
1012        self,
1013        right: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
1014        operation_class: Type['icepool.evaluator.ComparisonEvaluator'],
1015        *,
1016        truth_value_callback: 'Callable[[], bool] | None' = None
1017    ) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
1018        right = icepool.implicit_convert_to_expression(right)
1019
1020        if truth_value_callback is not None:
1021
1022            def data_callback() -> Counts[bool]:
1023                die = cast('icepool.Die[bool]',
1024                           operation_class().evaluate(self, right))
1025                if not isinstance(die, icepool.Die):
1026                    raise TypeError('Did not resolve to a die.')
1027                return die._data
1028
1029            return icepool.DieWithTruth(data_callback, truth_value_callback)
1030        else:
1031            return operation_class().evaluate(self, right)
1032
1033    def __lt__(self,
1034               other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
1035               /) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
1036        try:
1037            return self._compare(other,
1038                                 icepool.evaluator.IsProperSubsetEvaluator)
1039        except TypeError:
1040            return NotImplemented
1041
1042    def __le__(self,
1043               other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
1044               /) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
1045        try:
1046            return self._compare(other, icepool.evaluator.IsSubsetEvaluator)
1047        except TypeError:
1048            return NotImplemented
1049
1050    def issubset(
1051            self,
1052            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
1053            /) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
1054        """Evaluation: Whether this multiset is a subset of the other multiset.
1055
1056        Specifically, if this multiset has a lesser or equal count for each
1057        outcome than the other multiset, this evaluates to `True`; 
1058        if there is some outcome for which this multiset has a greater count 
1059        than the other multiset, this evaluates to `False`.
1060
1061        `issubset` is the same as `self <= other`.
1062        
1063        `self < other` evaluates a proper subset relation, which is the same
1064        except the result is `False` if the two multisets are exactly equal.
1065        """
1066        return self._compare(other, icepool.evaluator.IsSubsetEvaluator)
1067
1068    def __gt__(self,
1069               other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
1070               /) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
1071        try:
1072            return self._compare(other,
1073                                 icepool.evaluator.IsProperSupersetEvaluator)
1074        except TypeError:
1075            return NotImplemented
1076
1077    def __ge__(self,
1078               other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
1079               /) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
1080        try:
1081            return self._compare(other, icepool.evaluator.IsSupersetEvaluator)
1082        except TypeError:
1083            return NotImplemented
1084
1085    def issuperset(
1086            self,
1087            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
1088            /) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
1089        """Evaluation: Whether this multiset is a superset of the other multiset.
1090
1091        Specifically, if this multiset has a greater or equal count for each
1092        outcome than the other multiset, this evaluates to `True`; 
1093        if there is some  outcome for which this multiset has a lesser count 
1094        than the other multiset, this evaluates to `False`.
1095        
1096        A typical use of this evaluation is testing for the presence of a
1097        combo of cards in a hand, e.g.
1098
1099        ```python
1100        deck.deal(5) >= ['a', 'a', 'b']
1101        ```
1102
1103        represents the chance that a deal of 5 cards contains at least two 'a's
1104        and one 'b'.
1105
1106        `issuperset` is the same as `self >= other`.
1107
1108        `self > other` evaluates a proper superset relation, which is the same
1109        except the result is `False` if the two multisets are exactly equal.
1110        """
1111        return self._compare(other, icepool.evaluator.IsSupersetEvaluator)
1112
1113    def __eq__(  # type: ignore
1114            self,
1115            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
1116            /) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
1117        try:
1118
1119            def truth_value_callback() -> bool:
1120                return self.equals(other)
1121
1122            return self._compare(other,
1123                                 icepool.evaluator.IsEqualSetEvaluator,
1124                                 truth_value_callback=truth_value_callback)
1125        except TypeError:
1126            return NotImplemented
1127
1128    def __ne__(  # type: ignore
1129            self,
1130            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
1131            /) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
1132        try:
1133
1134            def truth_value_callback() -> bool:
1135                return not self.equals(other)
1136
1137            return self._compare(other,
1138                                 icepool.evaluator.IsNotEqualSetEvaluator,
1139                                 truth_value_callback=truth_value_callback)
1140        except TypeError:
1141            return NotImplemented
1142
1143    def isdisjoint(
1144            self,
1145            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
1146            /) -> 'icepool.Die[bool] | MultisetFunctionRawResult[T, bool]':
1147        """Evaluation: Whether this multiset is disjoint from the other multiset.
1148        
1149        Specifically, this evaluates to `False` if there is any outcome for
1150        which both multisets have positive count, and `True` if there is not.
1151
1152        Negative incoming counts are treated as zero counts.
1153        """
1154        return self._compare(other, icepool.evaluator.IsDisjointSetEvaluator)
1155
1156    # For helping debugging / testing.
1157    def force_order(self, force_order: Order) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
1158        """Forces outcomes to be seen by the evaluator in the given order.
1159
1160        This can be useful for debugging / testing.
1161        """
1162        if force_order == Order.Any:
1163            return self
1164        return icepool.operator.MultisetForceOrder(self,
1165                                                   force_order=force_order)

Abstract base class representing an expression that operates on single multisets.

There are three types of multiset expressions:

  • MultisetGenerator, which produce raw outcomes and counts.
  • MultisetOperator, which takes outcomes with one or more counts and produces a count.
  • MultisetVariable, which is a temporary placeholder for some other expression.

Expression methods can be applied to MultisetGenerators to do simple evaluations. For joint evaluations, try multiset_function.

Use the provided operations to build up more complicated expressions, or to attach a final evaluator.

Operations include:

Operation Count / notes
additive_union, + l + r
difference, - l - r
intersection, & min(l, r)
union, | max(l, r)
symmetric_difference, ^ abs(l - r)
multiply_counts, * count * n
divide_counts, // count // n
modulo_counts, % count % n
keep_counts count if count >= n else 0 etc.
unary + same as keep_counts_ge(0)
unary - reverses the sign of all counts
unique min(count, n)
keep_outcomes count if outcome in t else 0
drop_outcomes count if outcome not in t else 0
map_counts f(outcome, *counts)
keep, [] less capable than KeepGenerator version
highest less capable than KeepGenerator version
lowest less capable than KeepGenerator version
Evaluator Summary
issubset, <= Whether the left side's counts are all <= their counterparts on the right
issuperset, >= Whether the left side's counts are all >= their counterparts on the right
isdisjoint Whether the left side has no positive counts in common with the right side
< As <=, but False if the two multisets are equal
> As >=, but False if the two multisets are equal
== Whether the left side has all the same counts as the right side
!= Whether the left side has any different counts to the right side
expand All elements in ascending order
sum Sum of all elements
count The number of elements
any Whether there is at least 1 element
highest_outcome_and_count The highest outcome and how many of that outcome
all_counts All counts in descending order
largest_count The single largest count, aka x-of-a-kind
largest_count_and_outcome Same but also with the corresponding outcome
count_subset, // The number of times the right side is contained in the left side
largest_straight Length of longest consecutive sequence
largest_straight_and_outcome Same but also with the corresponding outcome
all_straights Lengths of all consecutive sequences in descending order
def additive_union( *args: Union[MultisetExpression[~T], Mapping[~T, int], Sequence[~T]]) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
160    def additive_union(
161        *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
162    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
163        """The combined elements from all of the multisets.
164
165        Same as `a + b + c + ...`.
166
167        Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.
168
169        Example:
170        ```python
171        [1, 2, 2, 3] + [1, 2, 4] -> [1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 4]
172        ```
173        """
174        expressions = tuple(
175            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
176        return icepool.operator.MultisetAdditiveUnion(*expressions)

The combined elements from all of the multisets.

Same as a + b + c + ....

Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.

Example:

[1, 2, 2, 3] + [1, 2, 4] -> [1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 4]
def difference( *args: Union[MultisetExpression[~T], Mapping[~T, int], Sequence[~T]]) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
195    def difference(
196        *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
197    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
198        """The elements from the left multiset that are not in any of the others.
199
200        Same as `a - b - c - ...`.
201
202        Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.
203
204        Example:
205        ```python
206        [1, 2, 2, 3] - [1, 2, 4] -> [2, 3]
207        ```
208
209        If no arguments are given, the result will be an empty multiset, i.e.
210        all zero counts.
211
212        Note that, as a multiset operation, this will only cancel elements 1:1.
213        If you want to drop all elements in a set of outcomes regardless of
214        count, either use `drop_outcomes()` instead, or use a large number of
215        counts on the right side.
216        """
217        expressions = tuple(
218            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
219        return icepool.operator.MultisetDifference(*expressions)

The elements from the left multiset that are not in any of the others.

Same as a - b - c - ....

Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.

Example:

[1, 2, 2, 3] - [1, 2, 4] -> [2, 3]

If no arguments are given, the result will be an empty multiset, i.e. all zero counts.

Note that, as a multiset operation, this will only cancel elements 1:1. If you want to drop all elements in a set of outcomes regardless of count, either use drop_outcomes() instead, or use a large number of counts on the right side.

def intersection( *args: Union[MultisetExpression[~T], Mapping[~T, int], Sequence[~T]]) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
238    def intersection(
239        *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
240    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
241        """The elements that all the multisets have in common.
242
243        Same as `a & b & c & ...`.
244
245        Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.
246
247        Example:
248        ```python
249        [1, 2, 2, 3] & [1, 2, 4] -> [1, 2]
250        ```
251
252        Note that, as a multiset operation, this will only intersect elements
253        1:1.
254        If you want to keep all elements in a set of outcomes regardless of
255        count, either use `keep_outcomes()` instead, or use a large number of
256        counts on the right side.
257        """
258        expressions = tuple(
259            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
260        return icepool.operator.MultisetIntersection(*expressions)

The elements that all the multisets have in common.

Same as a & b & c & ....

Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.

Example:

[1, 2, 2, 3] & [1, 2, 4] -> [1, 2]

Note that, as a multiset operation, this will only intersect elements 1:1. If you want to keep all elements in a set of outcomes regardless of count, either use keep_outcomes() instead, or use a large number of counts on the right side.

def union( *args: Union[MultisetExpression[~T], Mapping[~T, int], Sequence[~T]]) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
278    def union(
279        *args: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]'
280    ) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
281        """The most of each outcome that appear in any of the multisets.
282
283        Same as `a | b | c | ...`.
284
285        Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.
286
287        Example:
288        ```python
289        [1, 2, 2, 3] | [1, 2, 4] -> [1, 2, 2, 3, 4]
290        ```
291        """
292        expressions = tuple(
293            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
294        return icepool.operator.MultisetUnion(*expressions)

The most of each outcome that appear in any of the multisets.

Same as a | b | c | ....

Any resulting counts that would be negative are set to zero.

Example:

[1, 2, 2, 3] | [1, 2, 4] -> [1, 2, 2, 3, 4]
def symmetric_difference( self, other: Union[MultisetExpression[~T], Mapping[~T, int], Sequence[~T]], /) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
314    def symmetric_difference(
315            self,
316            other: 'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
317            /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
318        """The elements that appear in the left or right multiset but not both.
319
320        Same as `a ^ b`.
321
322        Specifically, this produces the absolute difference between counts.
323        If you don't want negative counts to be used from the inputs, you can
324        do `+left ^ +right`.
325
326        Example:
327        ```python
328        [1, 2, 2, 3] ^ [1, 2, 4] -> [2, 3, 4]
329        ```
330        """
331        return icepool.operator.MultisetSymmetricDifference(
332            self, implicit_convert_to_expression(other))

The elements that appear in the left or right multiset but not both.

Same as a ^ b.

Specifically, this produces the absolute difference between counts. If you don't want negative counts to be used from the inputs, you can do +left ^ +right.

Example:

[1, 2, 2, 3] ^ [1, 2, 4] -> [2, 3, 4]
def keep_outcomes( self, target: Union[Callable[[~T], bool], Collection[~T], MultisetExpression[~T]], /) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
334    def keep_outcomes(
335            self, target:
336        'Callable[[T], bool] | Collection[T] | MultisetExpression[T]',
337            /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
338        """Keeps the elements in the target set of outcomes, and drops the rest by setting their counts to zero.
339
340        This is similar to `intersection()`, except the right side is considered
341        to have unlimited multiplicity.
342
343        Args:
344            target: A callable returning `True` iff the outcome should be kept,
345                or an expression or collection of outcomes to keep.
346        """
347        if isinstance(target, MultisetExpression):
348            return icepool.operator.MultisetFilterOutcomesBinary(self, target)
349        else:
350            return icepool.operator.MultisetFilterOutcomes(self, target=target)

Keeps the elements in the target set of outcomes, and drops the rest by setting their counts to zero.

This is similar to intersection(), except the right side is considered to have unlimited multiplicity.

Arguments:
  • target: A callable returning True iff the outcome should be kept, or an expression or collection of outcomes to keep.
def drop_outcomes( self, target: Union[Callable[[~T], bool], Collection[~T], MultisetExpression[~T]], /) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
352    def drop_outcomes(
353            self, target:
354        'Callable[[T], bool] | Collection[T] | MultisetExpression[T]',
355            /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
356        """Drops the elements in the target set of outcomes by setting their counts to zero, and keeps the rest.
357
358        This is similar to `difference()`, except the right side is considered
359        to have unlimited multiplicity.
360
361        Args:
362            target: A callable returning `True` iff the outcome should be
363                dropped, or an expression or collection of outcomes to drop.
364        """
365        if isinstance(target, MultisetExpression):
366            return icepool.operator.MultisetFilterOutcomesBinary(self,
367                                                                 target,
368                                                                 invert=True)
369        else:
370            return icepool.operator.MultisetFilterOutcomes(self,
371                                                           target=target,
372                                                           invert=True)

Drops the elements in the target set of outcomes by setting their counts to zero, and keeps the rest.

This is similar to difference(), except the right side is considered to have unlimited multiplicity.

Arguments:
  • target: A callable returning True iff the outcome should be dropped, or an expression or collection of outcomes to drop.
def map_counts( *args: Union[MultisetExpression[~T], Mapping[~T, int], Sequence[~T]], function: Callable[..., int]) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
376    def map_counts(*args:
377                   'MultisetExpression[T] | Mapping[T, int] | Sequence[T]',
378                   function: Callable[..., int]) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
379        """Maps the counts to new counts.
380
381        Args:
382            function: A function that takes `outcome, *counts` and produces a
383                combined count.
384        """
385        expressions = tuple(
386            implicit_convert_to_expression(arg) for arg in args)
387        return icepool.operator.MultisetMapCounts(*expressions,
388                                                  function=function)

Maps the counts to new counts.

Arguments:
  • function: A function that takes outcome, *counts and produces a combined count.
def multiply_counts( self, n: int, /) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
401    def multiply_counts(self, n: int, /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
402        """Multiplies all counts by n.
403
404        Same as `self * n`.
405
406        Example:
407        ```python
408        Pool([1, 2, 2, 3]) * 2 -> [1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 2, 3, 3]
409        ```
410        """
411        return icepool.operator.MultisetMultiplyCounts(self, constant=n)

Multiplies all counts by n.

Same as self * n.

Example:

Pool([1, 2, 2, 3]) * 2 -> [1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 2, 3, 3]

443

446        Pool([1, 2, 2, 3]) // 2 -> [2]
447        ```
448        """

def modulo_counts( self, n: int, /) -> MultisetExpression[~T]: 
456    def modulo_counts(self, n: int, /) -> 'MultisetExpression[T]':
457        """Moduos all counts by n.
458
459        Same as `self % n`.
460
461        Example:
462        ```python
463        Pool([1, 2, 2, 3]) % 2 -> [1, 3]
464        ```
465        """
466        return self % n

Moduos all counts by n.

Same as self % n.
